Title.evidence: Intraoperative End-Tidal Carbon Dioxide and Recurrence-Free Survival in Pancreatic Cancer Surgery: A Retrospective Cohort Study

Participants.evidence: This single-center, retrospective cohort study included 652 patients who underwent elective pancreatic cancer resection at Heidelberg University Hospital between 2009 and 2016.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were categorized into high-EtCO2 and low-EtCO2 groups based on mean intraoperative EtCO2 values.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to explore the relationship between EtCO2 levels and recurrence-free survival in pancreatic cancer surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was recurrence-free survival, with secondary outcomes including cardiovascular events, surgical site infections, sepsis, reoperations, and overall survival.

Number_Analysed.evidence: This single-center, retrospective cohort study included 652 patients who underwent elective pancreatic cancer resection at Heidelberg University Hospital between 2009 and 2016.

Result_Outcome.evidence: There was no significant difference in recurrence-free survival between the high and low EtCO2 groups [HR = 1.043 (95% CI: 0.875–1.243), p = 0.909].

Harms.evidence: secondary outcomes including cardiovascular events, surgical site infections, sepsis, reoperations, and overall survival.
